newsitem.title: USA: CME live cattle end mixed, feeder cattle lower.
newsitem.headline: CME live cattle end mixed, feeder cattle lower.

text.p: CME live cattle closed narrowly mixed and feeder cattle mostly lower after a lightly traded session.

In live cattle, traders said short covering appeared to have supported the October contract. Tight supplies of market-ready cattle and the narrow premium of October to cash prices prompted the shortcovering, they said.

eeders are current and traders said sellers may be in a position to force higher bids from meat packers. Also, with October live cattle expiring Thursday, traders said December is priced well under current cash prices.
December closed at the equivalent of $65.100 per cwt versus current $69.00 bids in High Plains feedlot markets.
Also news of snow Monday from Kansas to Texas raised concerns an early winter could slow weight gains and delay cattle marketings to beyond the December delivery period.
Feeder cattle closed mostly lower. Lower deferred live cattle futures likely prompted selling in the nearby feeder contracts, traders said.
Also, the late rebound in CBOT corn was bearish for feeder cattle. CBOT corn closed steady to 0.50 cent per bushel higher after trading about one cent lower early.
Further, some traders said cash feeder cattle prices seasonally trend lower now as cattle are moved from summer pastures in the fall and into feedlots.
Live cattle futures were up 0.600 cent a lb to down 0.175 cent with December up 0.200 at 65.100 cents per lb. Feeder cattle were off 0.200 to up 0.100 cent with November off 0.150 at 63.200.
